title: The First Spell
description: Master the art of returning values to unlock the door ahead. Complete all quests to proceed.

lesson.title: Return Values: Your First Spell
content: In C, functions can send values back to their caller using the 'return' statement.
The return type (like 'int') tells C what kind of value your function will send back.
Think of return as casting a spell that produces a specific result - the value you return is the spell's effect!

examples.explanation: This function returns the integer 42. Simple and direct!
You can return the result of calculations. This returns the sum of a and b.

quests.title: The Secret Number
quests.description: Return the secret number 42 to prove your worth.
hints: Use the 'return' keyword to send a value back

teaching.explanation: The 'return' keyword sends a value back from a function. When C executes 'return 42;', the function immediately stops and the value 42 is given to whoever called the function.
teaching.tip: Every function with a return type (like 'int') MUST return a value. Forgetting 'return' is a common bug!

quests.title: Double Trouble
quests.description: The merchant wants twice his stock of 50 items. Return the doubled amount!
hints: You can use arithmetic in return statements

teaching.explanation: You don't have to return just a simple value - you can return the result of a calculation! 'return 50 * 2;' computes 100 and returns it in one step.
teaching.tip: C evaluates the expression FIRST, then returns the result. So 'return 2 + 3;' returns 5, not '2 + 3'.

quests.title: The Sum Spell
quests.description: Combine three power crystals: 25, 35, and 15 energy units. Return their combined power!

teaching.explanation: C lets you chain multiple operators in one expression. 'return 25 + 35 + 15;' adds all three numbers left-to-right: first 25+35=60, then 60+15=75.
teaching.tip: For readability, you can use parentheses to make order explicit: (25 + 35) + 15. Same result, clearer intent!

title: The Empty Backpack
description: The merchant needs help with calculations. Master arithmetic with parameters!

lesson.title: Variables and Arithmetic
content: Variables store data that your program can use and modify. In C, you must declare a variable's type before using it.
Function parameters are special variables that receive values when the function is called.
Arithmetic operators like + (add), - (subtract), * (multiply), and / (divide) work with numeric variables.

examples.explanation: Parameters x and y receive values from the caller, and we return their sum.
We can perform arithmetic on parameters and return the result.

quests.title: Adding Weights
quests.description: The merchant needs to calculate the total weight of two items.
hints: Use the + operator to add numbers
Return the sum: return item1 + item2;

teaching.explanation: Parameters are variables that receive values from outside the function. In 'int addWeight(int item1, int item2)', item1 and item2 are parameters - they get filled in when someone calls addWeight(10, 25).
teaching.tip: Parameters work just like regular variables inside your function. You can add them, compare them, or use them in any expression!

quests.title: Calculate Area
quests.description: Find the area of a rectangular storage crate.

teaching.explanation: The * operator multiplies two values. Just like addition, you can use it with parameters: 'return width * height;' computes the product.
teaching.tip: C follows standard math order: multiplication and division happen before addition and subtraction. Use parentheses if you need different order!

quests.title: Triple Sum
quests.description: Sum three item weights for the heavy load calculation.

teaching.explanation: Functions can take any number of parameters. Each one is separated by a comma in the declaration: 'int tripleSum(int a, int b, int c)' takes three integers.
teaching.tip: When calling a function with multiple parameters, order matters! tripleSum(1, 2, 3) assigns a=1, b=2, c=3 in that exact order.

title: The Gatekeeper
description: The guard tests your logic. Prove your worth with conditional decisions!

lesson.title: Conditional Logic with if/else
content: Programs often need to make decisions. The if/else statement lets your code choose between different paths based on conditions.
A condition is an expression that evaluates to true or false. Comparison operators include: > (greater), < (less), >= (greater or equal), <= (less or equal), == (equal), != (not equal).
The if block runs when the condition is true; the else block runs when it's false.

examples.explanation: Returns 1 if n is positive, 0 otherwise.
Returns a if it's bigger, otherwise returns b.

quests.title: Maximum Value
quests.description: Return the larger of two numbers to impress the guard.
hints: Return the larger value in each branch

teaching.explanation: The 'if' statement lets your code make decisions. When the condition in parentheses is true, the code inside the braces runs. 'if (a > b) { return a; }' returns a only when a is larger.
teaching.tip: Comparison operators: > (greater), < (less), >= (greater or equal), <= (less or equal), == (equal), != (not equal).

quests.title: Even or Odd
quests.description: Determine if a number is even (return 1) or odd (return 0).

teaching.explanation: The % operator gives the remainder after division. 7 % 2 equals 1 (7 divided by 2 leaves remainder 1). Even numbers always have n % 2 == 0 because they divide evenly by 2.
teaching.tip: Modulo is perfect for checking divisibility! n % 3 == 0 means n is divisible by 3. n % 10 gives the last digit of n.

quests.title: Clamp Value
quests.description: Keep a value within bounds: if below min, return min; if above max, return max.

teaching.explanation: You can chain multiple conditions with 'else if'. The code checks each condition in order and runs only the first matching block. This lets you handle multiple cases cleanly.
teaching.tip: Think of else if as a series of gates: C checks each one until it finds a match, then skips the rest. Order matters!

title: The Repeating Strike
description: Master the art of repetition with for loops!

lesson.title: Loops for Repetition
content: Loops let you repeat code multiple times. The for loop is perfect when you know how many times to repeat.
A for loop has three parts: initialization (int i = 1), condition (i <= n), and update (i++).
The loop body executes repeatedly while the condition is true. Use a variable to accumulate results across iterations.

examples.explanation: This loop adds 1+2+3+...+n by accumulating each value.
Multiplication through repeated addition.

quests.title: Sum of Strikes
quests.description: Calculate the sum of all strikes from 1 to n.
hints: Use a for loop: for(int i = 1; i <= n; i++)

teaching.explanation: A for loop repeats code a specific number of times. It has three parts: initialization (int i = 1), condition (i <= n), and increment (i++). The loop runs as long as the condition is true.
teaching.tip: Use a 'sum' variable initialized to 0, then add each value inside the loop: sum = sum + i; or shorter: sum += i;

quests.title: Factorial
quests.description: Compute n! (n factorial = n × (n-1) × ... × 1).

teaching.explanation: Just like summing, you can multiply in a loop. Start with result = 1 (not 0!), then multiply: result = result * i. For factorial, loop from 1 to n.
teaching.tip: Always initialize multiplication accumulators to 1, not 0. Anything times 0 stays 0!

quests.title: Count Divisible
quests.description: Count how many numbers from 1 to n are divisible by d.

teaching.explanation: Loops and if statements work great together. Loop through all numbers and use an if to check each one. When the condition is true, increment your counter.
teaching.tip: The pattern 'count++' is shorthand for 'count = count + 1'. It's commonly used inside loops to count matching items.

title: Array Fortress
description: A fortress of many rooms. Master array access and iteration!

lesson.title: Arrays: Collections of Data
content: Arrays let you store multiple values of the same type in a single variable. Each value has an index (position number).
IMPORTANT: Array indices start at 0! The first element is at index 0, the second at index 1, and so on.
Access array elements with square brackets: arr[0] gets the first element, arr[2] gets the third.

examples.explanation: Returns 10 - the element at index 0 (first position).
Returns 15 - the element at index 2 (third position).

quests.title: Room Access
quests.description: Return the value at a specific room index from {10, 20, 30, 40, 50}.
hints: Use rooms[index] to access the element

teaching.explanation: Access array elements using square brackets: arr[index]. In C, indices start at 0, so arr[0] is the first element, arr[1] is the second, and so on.
teaching.tip: CRITICAL: An array of size 5 has valid indices 0-4. Accessing arr[5] is a bug (out of bounds) that can crash your program!

quests.title: Sum All Rooms
quests.description: Sum all elements in the rooms array {10, 20, 30, 40, 50}.
hints: Use a for loop to iterate through the array
for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) sum += rooms[i]

teaching.explanation: Use a for loop to visit every element: for(int i = 0; i < size; i++). Access each element with arr[i]. This is the most common pattern in C!
teaching.tip: Use i < size (not i <= size) in your condition. This ensures you stay within bounds: 0, 1, 2, ..., size-1.

quests.title: Find Maximum
quests.description: Find the maximum value in {15, 42, 8, 23, 31}.
hints: Compare each element: if (values[i] > max) max = values[i]

teaching.explanation: To find the max, start with the first element as your 'best guess'. Then check each element: if it's bigger, update your max. This pattern works for any 'best' search.
teaching.tip: Initialize max with arr[0], not 0. Why? If all values are negative, 0 would be wrong! Same logic for minimum.

title: The Spell Scroll
description: Learn to create functions that perform actions without returning values.

lesson.title: Void Functions: Actions Without Returns
content: Not all functions need to return a value. Void functions perform actions (like printing or modifying data) without returning anything.
Declare with 'void' as the return type: void functionName() { }
Void functions are perfect for side effects: printing output, modifying values through pointers, or triggering events.
In these quests, you'll use void helpers to demonstrate the concept, then wrap them in testable functions that return confirmation values.

examples.explanation: The void function performs the action (printing), and the wrapper returns a value we can test.
The void function modifies through a pointer, and we return the result for testing.

quests.title: Cast Spell
quests.description: Create a void function that prints the magic word, then call it from a wrapper function.
hints: In castSpell(): call printSpell(); then return 1;
The void function does the work, the int function confirms it happened

teaching.explanation: A void function performs an action but doesn't return a value. The keyword 'void' means 'nothing'. Use void for actions like printing, modifying data, or triggering events.
teaching.tip: You can still use 'return;' (with no value) in a void function to exit early, but you cannot 'return' an actual value.

quests.title: Enchant Weapon
quests.description: Use a void function to add bonus damage through a pointer, then return the result.
hints: In addDamage(): modify through pointer with *damage += bonus;
The & operator gets the address of baseDamage so addDamage can modify it
After calling addDamage, baseDamage will have the new value - return it!

teaching.explanation: Void functions often modify data through pointers. The caller passes a memory address (&var), and the function uses *ptr to read/write the value at that address.
teaching.tip: Think of & as 'address of' and * as 'value at'. &baseDamage gives the address; *damage accesses what's stored there.

title: The Damage Calculator
description: Master complex return expressions that combine multiple operations.

lesson.title: Complex Return Expressions
content: Return statements can contain complex expressions that combine multiple operations.
You can use if/else inside a function to conditionally return different values.
Calculations can be chained together: (a + b + c) * bonus / divisor

examples.explanation: Returns the difference if positive, otherwise 0.
Adds values and applies a 10% bonus.

quests.title: Calculate Damage
quests.description: Return (base × mult) - armor, but never below 0.
hints: First calculate: int raw = base * mult;
Then check: if (raw > armor) return raw - armor;
Don't forget to return 0 for the else case

teaching.explanation: Complex problems often need multiple steps. Calculate intermediate results, store them in variables, then combine them. This makes code clearer and easier to debug.
teaching.tip: Breaking down 'damage = max(0, base*mult - armor)' into steps helps you see each part. Use temp variables like 'raw' freely!

quests.title: Critical Hit
quests.description: If isCrit is non-zero, return damage × 3, else return damage unchanged.
hints: Use if (isCrit != 0) to check for critical
return damage * 3; for critical, damage for normal

teaching.explanation: In C, 0 means false and ANY non-zero value means true. So 'if (isCrit)' is the same as 'if (isCrit != 0)'. This is why functions often return 1 for success/true.
teaching.tip: You can simplify 'if (x != 0)' to just 'if (x)'. Both check if x is 'truthy' (non-zero).

quests.title: Combo Attack
quests.description: Return the sum of three hits with a 10% bonus: (hit1 + hit2 + hit3) × 11 ÷ 10
hints: Use parentheses: (hit1 + hit2 + hit3) to sum first
Multiply by 11, then divide by 10 for 10% bonus
Order matters: * before / due to integer division

teaching.explanation: In C, dividing integers drops the decimal: 7/2 = 3, not 3.5. To add 10% bonus, multiply by 11 FIRST, then divide by 10. The order matters!
teaching.tip: When multiplying before dividing (like sum*11/10), you preserve more precision than dividing first (sum/10*11).

title: The Stack Spire
description: Understand how function calls create stack frames with private workspaces.

lesson.title: The Call Stack
content: When a function calls another function, the computer 'pauses' the caller and starts the new function.
Each function call creates a 'stack frame' - a private workspace with its own local variables.
When a function returns, its frame is removed and the caller resumes.
This is like stacking books - the last one added is the first one removed.

examples.explanation: When addTwo calls addOne, it pauses. Each addOne call gets its own stack frame with its own 'n' parameter.
Global variables persist across all frames, while local variables live only in their frame.

quests.title: Add One
quests.description: Create a simple helper that adds 1 to a number.

teaching.explanation: Small helper functions that do one thing well are building blocks of larger programs. addOne(n) just adds 1 - simple, but powerful when combined.
teaching.tip: Good functions have one clear purpose. A function called 'addOne' should ONLY add one - no surprises!

quests.title: Double Add One
quests.description: Call addOne twice: addOne(addOne(n)) to add 2.

teaching.explanation: Functions can call other functions! addOne(addOne(n)) first calls the inner addOne(n), gets a result, then passes it to the outer addOne. Each call creates a new stack frame.
teaching.tip: Read nested calls inside-out: addOne(addOne(5)) → addOne(6) → 7. The inner call completes first!

quests.title: Track Call Depth
quests.description: Use a global counter to track the maximum depth of recursive calls.
hints: Call trackDepth(n) to build the stack
Return maxDepth to show how deep the stack went

teaching.explanation: Recursive functions call themselves, adding a new stack frame each time. The 'depth' variable tracks how many frames are stacked. When a function returns, its frame is removed.
teaching.tip: Every recursive function needs a base case (when to stop) or it will overflow the stack! Here n > 1 is the check - when n reaches 1, no more recursive calls happen.

title: The Global Artifact
description: Master variable scope: global, function, and block level visibility.

lesson.title: Variable Scope
content: C has three levels of scope: GLOBAL (file-level), FUNCTION (parameters and locals), and BLOCK (inside {}).
Global variables (declared outside functions) are visible everywhere in the file.
Function scope includes parameters and variables declared at function level - visible throughout the function.
Block scope variables (declared inside {} like loops) only exist within that block.
If a local variable has the same name as a global, the local 'shadows' the global within its scope.

examples.explanation: Global scope: Functions can access global variables directly.
Block scope: temp only exists inside the loop's {}.

quests.title: Read Global
quests.description: Access the global artifact variable (value 100).
hints: Global variables are accessible from any function

teaching.explanation: Variables declared outside all functions are 'global' - visible everywhere in the file. Any function can read or modify them. Global 'artifact' is accessible from readGlobal().
teaching.tip: Globals are convenient but dangerous in large programs. Multiple functions can change them, making bugs hard to track. Use sparingly!

quests.title: Local Shadow
quests.description: A local parameter shadows the global. Return the local value.

teaching.explanation: When a local variable has the same name as a global, it 'shadows' (hides) the global. Inside that function, the name refers to the local variable, not the global.
teaching.tip: Shadowing is often confusing. Many style guides recommend avoiding it by using different names for local vs global variables.

quests.title: Block Scope Accumulator
quests.description: Sum values using a block-scoped temp variable that only exists inside the loop.
hints: Inside the loop: int temp = i * 2;
temp only exists within the for loop's {}

teaching.explanation: Variables declared inside {} braces only exist within that block. A variable declared inside a for loop is created and destroyed each iteration. It can't be accessed outside.
teaching.tip: Block scope keeps variables contained. Declaring 'int i' inside for() means it disappears after the loop - no leftover clutter!

title: The Recursive Mirror
description: Master functions that call themselves with base cases.

lesson.title: Recursion
content: Recursion is when a function calls itself to solve smaller subproblems.
Every recursive function needs a BASE CASE - the condition that stops recursion.
Ask yourself: 'What's the simplest case I can solve directly?' That's your base case.
Without a base case, recursion never stops - causing a stack overflow crash!
The recursive case breaks the problem into smaller pieces, moving toward the base case.

examples.explanation: Sums 1 to n by adding n to the sum of 1 to n-1. Base case: n <= 0 returns 0.

quests.title: Recursive Sum
quests.description: The mirror reflects your spell, adding its reflection to the original. Sum 1 to n using the mirror's recursive magic.
hints: WARNING: Without a base case, the mirror reflects forever - stack overflow crash!

teaching.explanation: Every recursive function needs a base case - when to STOP recursing. For sumToN, when n is 0 or less, we return 0 immediately without calling sumToN again.
teaching.tip: Think of recursion as asking: 'Can I solve this directly?' (base case) or 'Can I break this into a smaller version of the same problem?' (recursive case)

quests.title: Recursive Power
quests.description: Each reflection multiplies - mirrors within mirrors create exponential power. Calculate base^exp recursively.
hints: WARNING: Missing base case = infinite mirror loop = crash!
Base case: any number to the power 0 is 1
Recursive: multiply base by power(base, exp-1)

teaching.explanation: 2^3 = 2 * 2 * 2. Recursively: 2^3 = 2 * 2^2 = 2 * 2 * 2^1 = 2 * 2 * 2 * 2^0 = 2 * 2 * 2 * 1 = 8. Each recursive call reduces the exponent by 1.
teaching.tip: The base case (exp == 0 returns 1) is mathematically correct: any number to the power 0 equals 1. This also stops the recursion!

quests.title: Fibonacci
quests.description: The golden spiral emerges from the fibonacci mirrors. TWO base cases required: fib(0)=0 and fib(1)=1. What happens if you forget one?
hints: CRITICAL: Fibonacci needs TWO base cases! Missing one causes infinite recursion!

teaching.explanation: Fibonacci needs TWO base cases because fib(n) calls both fib(n-1) AND fib(n-2). Without both cases, one branch recurses forever. Always trace your recursive calls mentally!
teaching.tip: This naive Fibonacci is slow (exponential time) because it recalculates the same values repeatedly. Later you'll learn memoization to fix this!

title: The Address Spell
description: Learn to work with memory addresses through pointers.

lesson.title: Pointers and Memory Addresses
content: Every variable in C has a memory address where its value is stored.
A pointer is a variable that holds a memory address. Declare with: int *ptr;
In these quests, you RECEIVE pointers as parameters. In real programs, you also CREATE pointers using the & (address-of) operator.
The & operator gets a variable's address: int val = 42; int *ptr = &val;
When a function receives a pointer parameter, it can read the value at that address using the * (dereference) operator.

examples.explanation: The function receives an address and returns the value stored there using *.
Real-world example: Get a variable's address with &, then read through the pointer with *.

quests.title: Read Via Pointer
quests.description: Return the value stored at the address the pointer points to.
hints: Use *ptr to get the value at the address

teaching.explanation: A pointer holds a memory address. The * operator 'dereferences' it - follows the address to get the actual value stored there. If ptr points to 42, then *ptr gives 42.
teaching.tip: Think of * as 'value at address'. If ptr is like a street address, *ptr is what's inside that house.

quests.title: Add Via Pointers
quests.description: Return the sum of values at two different addresses.

teaching.explanation: Pointers are just variables - you can have as many as you need. Each one points to a different memory location. Dereference each with * to get its value.
teaching.tip: In expressions, * binds tightly: *a + *b means 'value at a' plus 'value at b'. Use parentheses if unsure: (*a) + (*b).

title: The Grappling Hook
description: Master pointer declarations and learn to grab values from a distance!

lesson.title: Declaring and Using Pointers
content: Declare a pointer with: int *ptr; (a pointer to an integer)
The * in declarations means 'pointer to'. In expressions, * means 'dereference'.
To make a pointer point to a variable, use the & operator: int *ptr = &variable;
This is the FULL pattern: declare pointer, assign address, then use the value.
Functions can modify values through pointers, allowing changes to persist outside the function.

examples.explanation: Reading a value through a pointer parameter.
Complete pattern: declare pointer, get address with &, use value with *.

quests.title: Grab the Value
quests.description: Return the value your pointer hook is aimed at.

teaching.explanation: When a function takes a pointer parameter (int *hook), it receives a memory address. The pointer lets you 'reach into' memory and access values indirectly.
teaching.tip: The pointer itself is passed by value (a copy of the address), but since both copies point to the same memory, you can modify the original data.

quests.title: Double the Treasure
quests.description: Return double the value at the pointer's location.

teaching.explanation: Once you dereference a pointer with *ptr, you get the actual value stored at that address. This value can be used in any expression: arithmetic (*ptr * 2), comparisons (*ptr > 10), or function calls.
teaching.tip: Think of *ptr as 'the value at ptr'. Anywhere you'd normally use a variable, you can use *ptr instead.

quests.title: Declare Local Pointer
quests.description: DECLARE a local pointer to val, ASSIGN its address, then return the value doubled.
hints: This quest requires DECLARING your own pointer!
int *ptr = &val; creates pointer and gets address
Full pattern: declare pointer, assign address with &, use value with *

teaching.explanation: The & operator gets the memory address of any variable. 'int *ptr = &val' creates a pointer and immediately assigns it the address of val. Now ptr 'points to' val.
teaching.tip: Reading right-to-left: &val gives address → stored in ptr → ptr is declared as int*. You can also split this: 'int *ptr; ptr = &val;'

title: The Dereference Pull
description: Learn to modify values through pointers - the key to powerful functions!

lesson.title: Modifying Values Through Pointers
content: The dereference operator (*) lets you both read AND write values at an address.
Writing: *ptr = value; changes what ptr points to.
Changes through *ptr persist because you are modifying the ORIGINAL variable at that address.
This is how functions can "return" multiple values - by modifying variables through pointers.
This is how functions can modify variables from their caller - by receiving pointers to those variables.

examples.explanation: Sets the value at ptr's address to 42.
Modifies through pointer and returns the new value.

quests.title: Set and Read
quests.description: Set the value at ptr to val and return it to confirm the change.

teaching.explanation: The dereference operator (*) works for BOTH reading and writing. '*ptr = val' writes the value of val into the memory location ptr points to. The original variable is permanently changed!
teaching.tip: Assignment to *ptr modifies the ORIGINAL data, not a copy. This is why functions use pointers to 'return' multiple values or modify caller's variables.

quests.title: Increment Through Pointer
quests.description: Increase the value at ptr by 1 and return the new value.

teaching.explanation: You can read, modify, and write back through a pointer in one expression: '*ptr = *ptr + 1' reads the value, adds 1, and stores it back. Shorthand: (*ptr)++ or ++(*ptr).
teaching.tip: The parentheses in (*ptr)++ are crucial! Without them, *ptr++ increments the POINTER, not the value. Operator precedence matters.

quests.title: Double In Place
quests.description: Double the value at ptr and return it.

teaching.explanation: All compound assignment operators work with dereferenced pointers: *ptr *= 2 doubles the value, *ptr += 5 adds 5, *ptr /= 2 halves it. These are shorthand for *ptr = *ptr op value.
teaching.tip: Compound assignments (*ptr *= 2) are more efficient and clearer than writing *ptr = *ptr * 2. Use them when modifying existing values.

title: The Array Navigator
description: Navigate arrays using pointer arithmetic - the foundation of efficient C programming!

lesson.title: Pointer Arithmetic and Arrays
content: In C, arrays and pointers are closely related. An array name IS a pointer to its first element.
Adding n to a pointer moves it forward by n elements: *(arr + 2) is the same as arr[2].
Use pointer arithmetic to traverse arrays efficiently in loops.

examples.explanation: Access element at index i using pointer arithmetic.
Sum array elements using pointer arithmetic in a loop.

quests.title: Navigate to Index
quests.description: Return the element at index i from the array using pointer arithmetic.
hints: Use *(arr + i) to access the element

teaching.explanation: When you add a number to a pointer, C moves by that many ELEMENTS (not bytes). *(arr + 2) means 'go 2 elements forward from arr, then dereference'. This is identical to arr[2].
teaching.tip: Array subscript notation arr[i] is just syntactic sugar for *(arr + i). Understanding this connection is key to mastering C.

quests.title: Sum Array Elements
quests.description: Sum all n elements of the array using pointer arithmetic.
hints: Use a for loop: for(int i = 0; i < n; i++)

teaching.explanation: To process all array elements, loop from 0 to n-1 and access each with *(arr + i). C doesn't know array sizes, so you MUST pass the size (n) separately to avoid going out of bounds.
teaching.tip: Always pass array size alongside the array pointer. Without n, there's no way to know where the array ends!

quests.title: Find Element Index
quests.description: Find the index of target in the array. Return -1 if not found.
hints: Loop through the array comparing each element
Return -1 after the loop if not found

teaching.explanation: Searching an array means checking each element until you find a match or exhaust all options. Return immediately when found (early exit), return a sentinel value (-1) if not found after checking all.
teaching.tip: The return -1 MUST be outside the loop. If it's inside, you'd return -1 after checking just the first element that doesn't match!

title: The Null Trap
description: Learn to safely handle null pointers and avoid the dreaded SEGFAULT!

lesson.title: Null Pointer Safety
content: NULL is a special pointer value meaning 'points to nothing'. Dereferencing NULL causes SEGMENTATION FAULT (crash)!
Where NULL comes from: malloc fails, you set ptr = NULL explicitly, or pointers are uninitialized.
ALWAYS check for NULL before dereferencing: if (ptr != NULL) { use *ptr }
Defensive programming: anticipate failure cases and handle them gracefully with NULL checks.

examples.explanation: Returns -1 for NULL, otherwise the actual value.
Returns 1 if pointer is valid, 0 if NULL.

quests.title: Safe Read
quests.description: Return the value at ptr, or -1 if ptr is NULL.

teaching.explanation: NULL is a special pointer value meaning 'points to nothing'. Dereferencing NULL (*ptr when ptr is NULL) causes a crash (segmentation fault). Always check BEFORE dereferencing!
teaching.tip: The pattern 'if (ptr == NULL) return error_value; return *ptr;' is the foundation of defensive programming in C.

quests.title: Is Valid Pointer
quests.description: Return 1 if the pointer is valid (not NULL), 0 if NULL.

teaching.explanation: Comparing a pointer to NULL yields a boolean (0 or 1). 'ptr != NULL' returns 1 if valid, 0 if NULL. You can also write 'ptr' alone as a condition - a non-NULL pointer is 'truthy'.
teaching.tip: In C, any non-zero value is true. So 'if (ptr)' works the same as 'if (ptr != NULL)' - though explicit NULL checks are more readable.

quests.title: Safe Add
quests.description: Return *a + *b if both pointers are valid. Return 0 if either is NULL.
hints: Check both: if (a == NULL || b == NULL)

teaching.explanation: When using multiple pointers, check ALL of them before dereferencing ANY. Use logical OR (||) to combine checks: 'if (a == NULL || b == NULL)' returns true if EITHER is invalid.
teaching.tip: Check for failure first, return early, then proceed with the 'happy path'. This 'guard clause' pattern keeps your code flat and readable.

title: The Blueprint Scroll
description: Learn to group related data together using structs!

lesson.title: Structs: Custom Data Types
content: A struct groups related variables together into a single unit.
Define with: struct Name { type field; };
Create: struct Name variable;
Access members with dot notation: variable.field

examples.explanation: Define struct, create variable, and set fields using dot notation.
Create struct inside function and access its members.

quests.title: Get Hero HP
quests.description: Create a Hero struct, populate it, and return its hp field.
hints: Define struct Hero { int hp; int level; };
Set fields: h.hp = hp_val; h.level = level_val;

teaching.explanation: A struct groups related variables into one unit. 'struct Hero { int hp; int level; };' defines the blueprint. Create an instance with 'struct Hero h;', then access fields with the dot operator: h.hp, h.level.
teaching.tip: Think of a struct as a custom data type. Just like 'int x;' creates an integer, 'struct Hero h;' creates a Hero containing multiple values.

quests.title: Is Hero Alive
quests.description: Create a Hero struct and return 1 if its hp > 0, else 0.
hints: Create struct Hero h and populate it

teaching.explanation: Struct fields are regular values you can use anywhere. 'h.hp > 0' compares the hp field to 0, returning 1 (true) or 0 (false). Struct members work in all expressions just like regular variables.
teaching.tip: The expression 'h.hp > 0' evaluates to 1 or 0, which you can return directly. No if/else needed!

quests.title: Calculate Power Level
quests.description: Create a Hero struct and compute its power: hp + (level × 10).
hints: Create struct Hero h and populate it
Access both fields: h.hp and h.level

teaching.explanation: You can combine struct fields in any expression: 'h.hp + h.level * 10' reads both fields and computes a result. The struct keeps related data together, making your code more organized.
teaching.tip: Structs are perfect for game entities! A Hero with hp/level is cleaner than separate variables hp_hero1, level_hero1, hp_hero2...

title: The Chest Contents
description: Access and compute with struct member values!

lesson.title: Working with Struct Members
content: Use dot notation to access struct members: chest.gold
Create struct variables and populate their fields
Members can be read, modified, and used in calculations
Each field acts like a regular variable of its type

examples.explanation: Define struct, create variable, and populate fields.
Create and access struct members using dot notation.

quests.title: Get Gold Count
quests.description: Create a Chest struct, populate it, and return the gold field.
hints: Define struct Chest { int gold; int gems; int keys; };
Set all fields: c.gold = gold_val; etc.

teaching.explanation: Structs can have many fields of any type. Initialize each field separately: c.gold = gold_val; c.gems = gems_val; c.keys = keys_val; Each field is independent.
teaching.tip: Field order in the struct definition doesn't affect how you access them. c.keys works regardless of where 'keys' appears in the struct definition.

quests.title: Total Chest Value
quests.description: Create a Chest struct, populate it, and compute the total value.
hints: Create and populate struct Chest c
Access all fields: c.gold, c.gems, c.keys

teaching.explanation: Use struct fields in formulas just like regular variables. 'c.gold + c.gems*10 + c.keys*5' calculates a weighted sum using all three fields. The struct keeps related data together for cleaner code.
teaching.tip: Structs make complex calculations readable. Compare 'chest.gold + chest.gems*10' vs 'gold1 + gems1*10' - the struct version is self-documenting.

quests.title: Is Chest Empty
quests.description: Create a Chest struct, populate it, and return 1 if all fields are 0.
hints: Create and populate struct Chest c

teaching.explanation: Use && (AND) to check multiple conditions: 'c.gold == 0 && c.gems == 0 && c.keys == 0' is true only if ALL fields are zero. The entire expression returns 1 or 0.
teaching.tip: The expression itself evaluates to 1 or 0, so 'return c.gold == 0 && c.gems == 0 && c.keys == 0;' works directly - no if statement needed!

title: The Teleport Chest
description: Modify struct values through pointers using the arrow operator!

lesson.title: Struct Pointers and Arrow Operator
content: When you have a pointer to a struct, use -> to access members
ptr->field is shorthand for (*ptr).field
This lets functions modify struct data in the caller's scope

examples.explanation: Create a struct, get pointer to it, use -> to modify its members.

quests.title: Add Gold via Arrow
quests.description: Create a Chest struct, use a pointer with -> to add gold, return the new total.

teaching.explanation: When you have a POINTER to a struct, use -> to access members. 'ptr->gold' means 'the gold field of the struct that ptr points to'. It's shorthand for (*ptr).gold.
teaching.tip: Use . with struct variables (c.gold), use -> with struct pointers (ptr->gold). This distinction is crucial in C!

quests.title: Modify Two Fields
quests.description: Use arrow operator to set both gold and gems, then return their sum.
hints: Create struct and pointer as before
Return the sum using ptr-> for both

teaching.explanation: The arrow operator works for both reading (return ptr->gold) and writing (ptr->gold = value). You can access multiple fields through the same pointer: ptr->gold + ptr->gems.
teaching.tip: The pattern 'struct X x; struct X *p = &x;' lets you use both syntaxes: x.field or p->field refer to the same data.

quests.title: Upgrade Chest
quests.description: Double the gold value through pointer, add bonus gems, return new gold.
hints: Arrow operator works for both reading and writing

teaching.explanation: All compound operators work with ->: ptr->gold *= 2 doubles the gold, ptr->gold += 10 adds 10. This modifies the original struct because you're working through a pointer.
teaching.tip: This is how real C code modifies structs: pass a pointer to a function, use -> to update fields. The changes persist after the function returns!

title: The Guild Hierarchy
description: Work with structs that contain other structs - hierarchical data!

lesson.title: Nested Structs
content: Structs can contain other structs, creating hierarchical data
Access nested fields with chained dots: guild.leader.level
Initialize with nested braces: struct Guild g = {{100, 5}, 10};

examples.explanation: Create nested structs and access members with chained dot notation.

quests.title: Access Nested Level
quests.description: Create nested Hero/Guild structs, return the leader's level using chained dots.
hints: Create Hero first, then assign to Guild's leader field
Chained dots for nested struct access

teaching.explanation: A struct can contain another struct as a member. 'g.leader' gives you the Hero struct inside Guild, then '.level' accesses that Hero's level field. Chain the dots: g.leader.level.
teaching.tip: Read left-to-right: g → leader (a Hero) → level (an int). Each dot takes you one level deeper into the nested structure.

quests.title: Calculate Guild Power
quests.description: Use nested structs to compute power: leader.level × memberCount.

teaching.explanation: You can initialize nested structs inline: 'struct Guild g = {h, memberCount}' sets g.leader = h and g.memberCount = memberCount. Mix nested access with regular fields: g.leader.level * g.memberCount.
teaching.tip: The initializer {h, memberCount} maps values in order to struct fields. The inner struct h is assigned to the first field (leader).

title: The Army Roster
description: Process arrays of structured data - the foundation of real programs!

lesson.title: Arrays of Structs
content: Arrays can hold structs just like they hold integers
Access with: array[i].field (combines array indexing and struct access)
Loop through to process all elements: for(int i = 0; i < n; i++)

examples.explanation: Create array of structs, populate, then iterate with array[i].field syntax.

quests.title: Sum Army Strength
quests.description: Create array of Soldier structs, populate from parameters, sum using loop.
hints: struct Soldier army[3]; declares array of 3 Soldiers
Loop: for(int i = 0; i < 3; i++) sum += army[i].strength;

teaching.explanation: 'struct Soldier army[3]' creates an array of 3 Soldier structs. Access elements by index first, then field: army[0].strength, army[1].strength, army[2].strength.
teaching.tip: The order matters: army[i] gives you one Soldier struct, then .strength accesses that soldier's strength field.

quests.title: Find Strongest Soldier
quests.description: Create soldier array, find index with maximum strength.
hints: Update maxIdx when you find larger value

teaching.explanation: To find the max in a struct array, track the INDEX of the best element, not just the value. Compare using: if(army[i].strength > army[maxIdx].strength). This lets you return the position, not just the value.
teaching.tip: Tracking the index is more flexible - you can then access ANY field of the winning element (army[maxIdx].name, army[maxIdx].level, etc.).

quests.title: Count Elite Soldiers
quests.description: Count soldiers with strength >= threshold using array iteration.
hints: Combine array access with struct member access

teaching.explanation: Loop through the array, check each element against your criteria, increment a counter when the condition is met. This pattern handles any 'count matching items' task: count elite soldiers, count items above a price, count players with high scores.
teaching.tip: The pattern 'initialize count to 0, loop, conditionally increment' is universal. You can count ANY criteria by changing the condition inside the if statement.

title: Summon Land
description: The void stretches before you. Use malloc to summon solid ground from nothingness!

lesson.title: Dynamic Memory with Malloc
content: malloc (memory allocate) requests memory from the system at runtime.
CRITICAL: malloc can fail and return NULL if memory is exhausted!
ALWAYS check: int *ptr = malloc(...); if (ptr == NULL) { handle error }
Always free() when done to prevent memory leaks.

examples.explanation: Safe malloc pattern: allocate, check NULL, use, free.

quests.title: Allocate and Read
quests.description: Malloc an integer, store the given value, read it back, free, and return.
hints: SAFETY: Check if malloc returns NULL!
Don't forget to free(p) before returning!

teaching.explanation: malloc() requests memory from the system, returning a pointer to that memory. CRITICAL: malloc can fail and return NULL if memory is exhausted! The safe pattern is: allocate, check for NULL, use, save result, free, return. Never return without freeing!
teaching.tip: Always check malloc's return value: if (p == NULL) return -1; This prevents crashes when memory is low. In production code, this check is mandatory.

quests.title: Allocate and Compute
quests.description: Malloc an integer, compute a + b, store it, read back, free, and return.
hints: Compute a + b and store in allocated memory
Read back with int result = *p; before freeing

teaching.explanation: Dynamically allocated memory works just like any other memory. After malloc, you can perform any operation: *p = a + b stores the sum just like with a stack variable. The key is remembering to free when done.
teaching.tip: The workflow is always: malloc → check NULL → compute → save result → free → return. Keeping this order prevents both leaks and use-after-free bugs.

title: The Banish Spell
description: What you summon, you must also banish! Release the memory back to the void.

lesson.title: Releasing Memory with Free
content: Every malloc must have a matching free, or you create a memory leak.
DANGER: After free(ptr), the pointer is 'dangling' - using it crashes!
Safe pattern: save result before freeing, then return the saved value.
Never return a freed pointer - it points to released memory!

examples.explanation: Allocate, compute, save result, free, then return the saved result.

quests.title: Square and Free
quests.description: Allocate memory, compute n squared, save result, free memory, return result.
hints: Save result before freeing: int result = *p;
WARNING: After free(p), never use *p again! Save result first: int result = *p; free(p); return result;

teaching.explanation: After free(p), the pointer becomes 'dangling' - it still holds the address, but that memory is no longer yours. Accessing *p after free causes undefined behavior (crashes, corruption). Always save the result BEFORE freeing: int result = *p; free(p); return result;
teaching.tip: Think of free() as 'forget this address'. The pointer variable still exists, but the memory it pointed to is gone. Some programmers set p = NULL after freeing to make accidental use obvious.

quests.title: Double Allocation
quests.description: Allocate TWO integers, store a and b, compute sum, free both, return sum.

teaching.explanation: When you have multiple allocations, each needs its own free(). The order usually doesn't matter, but you must free ALL of them. Forgetting even one causes a memory leak. Track your allocations: if you malloc twice, free twice.
teaching.tip: A good practice: declare all pointers at the top, initialize to NULL, and free all at the end. This makes it easier to verify every malloc has a matching free.

title: The Cursed Hoarding
description: A curse afflicts those who hoard without releasing! Learn proper cleanup patterns.

lesson.title: Avoiding Memory Leaks
content: A memory leak is allocated memory that's never freed - lost forever!
In the game world, leaks spawn void creatures that consume your realm.
In loops: free each allocation before the next iteration.
In branches: ensure ALL code paths call free before returning.

examples.explanation: Each allocation is freed within its iteration - no leaks. If free() were outside the loop, all but the last allocation would leak!

quests.title: Loop Cleanup
quests.description: Sum values 0 to n-1 using malloc in a loop. Free properly each iteration!
hints: SAFETY: Every malloc inside a loop must have a matching free inside that same loop!
Free inside the loop, not after!

teaching.explanation: When malloc is inside a loop, each iteration creates NEW memory. If you wait to free until after the loop, only the LAST allocation's pointer survives - all others are lost forever (leaked). The fix: free INSIDE the loop, at the end of each iteration.
teaching.tip: The pattern is: allocate → use → free, all within the same iteration. If your free() is outside the loop, you have a leak. Count your mallocs and frees - they should match!

quests.title: Branch Cleanup
quests.description: Allocate memory, return different values based on condition, but always free!
hints: SAFETY: Test BOTH paths (flag=0 and flag=1) to ensure proper cleanup!
Save result before freeing: int result = ...;
free(p); must happen before EVERY return
Or: compute result first, free, then return

teaching.explanation: Every code path that can return must free allocated memory first. If you have 'if (flag) return x; else return y;', BOTH branches need free() calls before their returns. Missing even one path causes a leak.
teaching.tip: Refactor to have a SINGLE return point: compute the result first, store it, free everything, then return. This guarantees cleanup happens regardless of which branch was taken.

title: The Expanding Army
description: Your army grows! Use realloc to expand arrays when needed.

lesson.title: Growing Arrays with Realloc
content: realloc resizes allocated memory, preserving existing data.
DANGER: realloc can fail and return NULL, losing your original pointer!
SAFE PATTERN: int *temp = realloc(arr, newSize); if(temp) arr = temp;
Always check realloc result before assigning back to original pointer.

examples.explanation: Safe realloc: save to temp, check NULL, then assign back.

quests.title: Grow and Sum
quests.description: Malloc for 1 int, store a, realloc to 2 ints, store b, return sum.
hints: SAFE realloc: int *temp = realloc(arr, size); if(temp) arr = temp;
int *temp = realloc(arr, 2 * sizeof(int)); if (temp) arr = temp; arr[1] = b;
Don't forget to free(arr) before returning!

teaching.explanation: realloc() can FAIL and return NULL, just like malloc. The danger: 'arr = realloc(arr, size)' overwrites arr with NULL on failure, losing your only pointer to the original memory! Always use a temp: 'int *temp = realloc(arr, size); if (temp) arr = temp;'
teaching.tip: The safe pattern preserves your original pointer until you're sure realloc succeeded. If temp is NULL, you can still free(arr) and handle the error gracefully.

quests.title: Triple Grow
quests.description: Start with malloc(1), realloc twice to reach size 3, store a,b,c, return sum.
hints: Each realloc grows by one element

teaching.explanation: realloc can grow memory multiple times. Each call may move the data to a new location (if there's no room to expand in place), but it preserves existing values. You can realloc(arr, 2), then realloc(arr, 3), each time adding capacity.
teaching.tip: In real programs, growing by 1 each time is inefficient. The common pattern is to double the size each time (capacity *= 2), which gives amortized O(1) insertions. But for learning, growing by 1 makes the concept clearer.

title: Chain of Portals
description: Create chains of nodes that point to each other - the foundation of linked lists!

lesson.title: Linked Lists
content: A linked list is a chain of nodes, each containing data and a pointer to the next node.
struct Node { int value; struct Node *next; }; defines a self-referential struct.
Traverse by following next pointers until you hit NULL (end of list).

examples.explanation: Traverse from head to end, counting nodes.

quests.title: Create a Node
quests.description: Allocate a Node, set its value, set next to NULL, return the value.
hints: int result = n->value; free(n); return result;

teaching.explanation: A linked list node contains a pointer to ANOTHER node of the same type: 'struct Node *next;'. This creates a chain where each node can point to the next. The last node's 'next' is NULL, marking the end of the chain.
teaching.tip: Always initialize next to NULL when creating a node. An uninitialized pointer contains garbage, and following it will crash your program. NULL is the sentinel that says 'this is the end'.

quests.title: Sum Node Values
quests.description: Sum all values by traversing the linked list.
hints: Create 3 nodes and link them: n1->next = n2; n2->next = n3; n3->next = NULL;
Traverse and sum: while(curr != NULL) { sum += curr->value; curr = curr->next; }

teaching.explanation: To visit every node: start at head, process current node, move to next, repeat until NULL. The pattern 'while(curr != NULL) { ... curr = curr->next; }' is the fundamental list traversal. Unlike arrays, you can't jump to index i - you must walk there.
teaching.tip: Create nodes from back to front: make the last node first (with next=NULL), then create earlier nodes pointing to it. This builds the chain correctly: n1->n2->n3->NULL.

quests.title: Last Value
quests.description: Create a 3-node list (a->b->c), traverse to find the last value, return it.
hints: When curr->next is NULL, curr is the last node
Return curr->value after saving it, then free all nodes

teaching.concept: Finding the End of a List
teaching.explanation: To find the last node, traverse until you find a node whose 'next' is NULL. The condition 'while(curr->next != NULL)' stops AT the last node (not past it). This is different from 'while(curr != NULL)' which stops AFTER the last node.
teaching.tip: The two traversal conditions serve different purposes: 'curr != NULL' for processing all nodes (curr ends up NULL), 'curr->next != NULL' for finding the last node (curr ends up at the final node). Choose based on what you need.
